text: (upbeat music)
(gentle music)
- I've always had a passion
for building things and using my hands.
My parents were telling me,
"Oh yeah, in Umatilla
there's this really good robotics team."
So I was like, "Robotics team?"

Okay, so I'll try my
best to get into this.
- My teacher brought up to me like,
"Oh, I'm doing the robotics program.
I'd really want you to be a part of it."
And I talked to my mom.
I was like, "Eh, I don't know.
I've never really done that before.
I don't know if I'd like it.
I don't know if I'd be good at it."
And she said, "You're gonna do it."

- My journey to joining
the robotics team started
back in seventh grade.

All the down here is our
chassis and our driveways
but our main problem right now is our arm.

I enjoy the build and the
hard, the stressful work

before you can actually
go into competition.

- Why do they start one or
two cameras on the robot?

- Because one camera can
see the cone really well
and one can see the cube really well.
- Ah, okay.

My favorite thing about
robotics is just learning a lot
about myself and others.
My social skills has improved a lot
'cause I used to not talk to anyone
and this, since I'm scout lead,
I have to start talking with everyone.
(bright upbeat music)

- First Robotics is an
international robotics competition
of high school kids.
They have eight weeks to build the robot

and engineer it, learn
to drive it, practice it,
and be ready for competition.
This is the first time
we've really been able to meet actually
and have an official conversation.
So what do you guys think?

What's something that you
would like to improve on
and do this year?
- My personal goal and also team-wide goal
is to get the new technology and devices
that we're gonna be getting from AWS
ready for the new robotics year.

With the new CNC machine, it'll
change our game completely
from doing simple caveman manufacturing
to real industrial manufacturing.
Instead of doing just flat pieces,
we will be able to do 3D models

of blocks of aluminum, brass,
whatever metal we have.

- [Nestor] Also from the AWS,
we're getting a lot of other

computing devices for
individuals within the team.
So a lot more people now have access
to do their work on the go or away

or just have a mobile
workstation with them.
So here in Umatilla we're pretty small
but we're very close together.
- [Avery] Everyone knows everyone.
We have these such strong connections
and people willing to help us

people who support us and
it makes it feel like home.

- Today it is the start of
our robotics competition
and we have a lot of alumni AWS employees
who have come out and helped.
- Well, behind me is the CNC machine

and that was purchased through
the partnership with AWS.
The school would never have been able
to afford this on their own.
It's an $80,000 machine.

- [Kaidan] No one else on
this side of the state has one

and no other public
institution in Oregon has one.
- This is my first ever kickoff

and I'm just excited
what my team is gonna do.

- I just really wanna see our
team do really well this year
and we have a lot of new people
and majority are freshmen.
It's a lot of training to do.
- We're not gonna have much time

outside of the shop for
the next seven weeks.
Some of us are gonna basically live here.

- [Avery] I just can't
wait to be finally back
and having everyone around again

and to just be in the shop
as like, joining as a family.

- When you spend all
this time with your team

you know what they like,
you know their birthday,
what makes them laugh, it's just...

It's really the stuff
that makes you really care
and wanna win as a team.

- [Avery] Robotics has
done wonders for me.

- [Nestor] Now I'm definitely
gonna go to college
because I want to have that experience.

Robotics has opened my
view of what I can do.

- [Kaidan] You learn
stem, you learn all these
technology skills and everything.

Then another way you learn
is communicating with people.
- [Avery] I used to hate public speaking
but then reaching out to these people
and talking to them because it was my job,
like I had to do it.
It taught me that it's not so bad.

- [Kaidan] I kind of
want to go get my degree
and then just come back to the community
and return it back to them.

- [Avery] It's given me
opportunities to open my eyes
like working in IT, that was something

that I never thought I
would do or even enjoy,
but it turns out I can do it.

- I wanna do something in
engineering, definitely.

I mean, if I could get
paid doing robotics,
it would be like, just kind of a dream.

- [Kaidan] I've put a lot
of my life towards this,
my whole high school career.
It's a thing that ties us all together.

It's not kids building robots,
it's robots building kids.
(soft pulsating music)
